Kerry Burtnyk.label: Kerry Burtnyk
Kerry Burtnyk.description: Kerry Burtnyk is a Canadian curler from Winnipeg, Manitoba. He grew up in Reston, Manitoba. He is a two time Canadian champion skip, and the 1995 World Champion skip. Wikipedia

Nicole Joraanstad.label: Nicole Joraanstad
Nicole Joraanstad.description: Nicole Joraanstad is an American curler from Verona, Wisconsin. She currently plays third for Allison Pottinger. Wikipedia

Pete Fenson.label: Pete Fenson
Pete Fenson.description: Peter Fenson is an American curler, skip of the men's rink which represented the United States at the 2006 Winter Olympics. The rink took the bronze medal, the first ever Olympic medal for the United States in curling. Wikipedia

Randy Ferbey.label: Randy Ferbey
Randy Ferbey.description: Randy Ferbey is a retired Canadian curler from Sherwood Park, Alberta. Ferbey is a six-time Canadian champion and a four-time World Champion. Wikipedia

Ted Appelman.label: Ted Appelman
Ted Appelman.description:
Ted Appelman is a Canadian curler from Edmonton, Alberta.
Appelman has made most of his successes to date as a skip, during the 2008-09 curling season and the 2009-10 curling season. Wikipedia

Andrey Drozdov.label: Andrey Drozdov
Andrey Drozdov.description: Andrey Anatolyevich Drozdov is a Russian curler from Zelenograd. He skips one of the Russian national teams, and is the first Russian men's skip to ever play in the World Championships and first man to skip Russia at the Olympics. Wikipedia

Elisabet Gustafson.label: Elisabet Gustafson
Elisabet Gustafson.description: Elisabet Gustafson is a retired Swedish curler, world champion and Olympic medalist. She has won four World Championships, more World Championships than any other women's curler. Wikipedia

Pat Simmons (curler).label: Pat Simmons
Pat Simmons (curler).description: Pat Simmons is a Canadian curler. Simmons presently plays third for the 2014 Canadian champion Kevin Koe rink from Calgary, Alberta. Wikipedia

Rhona Martin.label: Rhona Martin
Rhona Martin.description: Rhona Howie MBE, better known under her married name, Rhona Martin, is a British curler most famous for skipping the British women's team at the 2002 Winter Olympics, where the team claimed the gold medal. Wikipedia

Sean Becker.label: Sean Michael Becker
Sean Becker.description: Sean Michael Becker is an American film director, film producer and editor who is best known for directing Felicia Day's web series, The Guild. Wikipedia
Sean Becker.Born: February 17, 1981 (age 33), San Jose, California, United States

Moe Meguro.label: Moe Meguro
Moe Meguro.description: Moe Meguro is a Japanese curler. She was born on November 20, 1984 in Sorachi District, Hokkaidō. Wikipedia

Wang Bingyu.label: Wang Bingyu
Wang Bingyu.description: Wang Bingyu is a Chinese curler. She is currently the skip of the Chinese national team. In 2009 she became the first non Northern American or European skip to win a World Championships. Wikipedia

Wang Fengchun.label: Wang Fengchun
Wang Fengchun.description:
Wang Fengchun is a Chinese curler. He is the skip of the national team.
Wang was selected by the Chinese government to play the sport of curling. In China, the national team curls as their profession. Wikipedia

Binia Feltscher-Beeli.label: Binia Feltscher-Beeli
Binia Feltscher-Beeli.description: Binia Feltscher is a Swiss curler. She is the skip of the current World championship curling team from Switzerland. Wikipedia

Jenn Hanna.label: Jenn Hanna
Jenn Hanna.description: Jennifer Ann Hanna is a Canadian curler who curls out of the Ottawa Curling Club. She was a finalist in both the 1998 Canadian Junior Curling Championship and the 2005 Scott Tournament of Hearts. Wikipedia

Christina Bertrup.label: Christina Bertrup
Christina Bertrup.description:
Christina Bertrup is a Swedish curler. She presently throws third rock for Margaretha Sigfridsson.
Bertrup began her international curling career as the alternate player for Elisabet Gustafson. Wikipedia

Mathew Camm.label: Mathew Camm
Mathew Camm.description:
Mathew Robert "Mat" Camm is a Canadian curler from Rockland, Ontario.
Camm is originally from Rockland, Ontario. In 2007, Camm played lead for the Neil Sinclair rink which won the Ontario Bantam boy's championship. Wikipedia

Marcel Rocque.label: Marcel Rocque
Marcel Rocque.description: Marcel Rocque is a Canadian curler home to the city of Edmonton, Alberta. He is a four-time winner of The Brier, the annual Canadian men's curling championship and a three-time World Champion as the lead for the Randy Ferbey team. Wikipedia

Cathy Auld.label: Cathy Auld
Cathy Auld.description: Catherine "Cathy" Auld is a Canadian curler, who currently skips her own team out of the Mississaugua Golf & Country Club in Mississauga, Ontario. Wikipedia

Kristie Moore.label: Kristie Moore
Kristie Moore.description: Kristie Moore is a Canadian curler. She was the alternate player on the Canadian women's team at the 2010 Winter Olympics. She was five months pregnant at the time, making her only the third Olympic athlete to be pregnant during Olympic competition. Wikipedia

Xu Xiaoming.label: Xu Xiaoming
Xu Xiaoming.description: Xu Xiaoming is an internationally elite curler from China. Wikipedia

Adam Enright.label: Adam Enright
Adam Enright.description: Adam Enright is a Canadian curler from Edmonton. He is a former alternate for Kevin Martin's rink with whom he won a gold medal at the 2010 Winter Olympics as well as wins at the 2008 Tim Hortons Brier and the 2008 World Men's Curling Championship. Wikipedia

Bob Ursel.label: Bob Ursel
Bob Ursel.description:
Bob "Bobby" Ursel is a Canadian curler who curls out of Kelowna, British Columbia.
In 1984, Ursel skipped his native Manitoba to a Canadian Junior Curling Championship. Wikipedia

Cathy King.label: Cathy King
Cathy King.description: Cathy King, formerly Cathy Borst is a Canadian curler from St. Albert, Alberta. She is a former Canadian champion skip and world championship bronze medalist, and 2013 world senior champion. Wikipedia

Daley Peters.label: Daley Peters
Daley Peters.description: Daley Peters is a Canadian curler from Winnipeg, Manitoba. He was back to back Manitoba Junior curling champion in 2004 and 2005, the first Junior Mens skip to repeat in Manitoba in nearly a decade. Wikipedia

David Nedohin.label: David Nedohin
David Nedohin.description: David Nedohin is a Canadian curler from Sherwood Park, Alberta. He is best known as the longtime fourth for Randy Ferbey. Wikipedia

Dawn Askin.label: Dawn McEwen
Dawn Askin.description: Dawn McEwen is a Canadian curler from Winnipeg, Manitoba. She currently plays lead for the Jennifer Jones rink, who became Olympic champions, winning gold for Canada at the 2014 Winter Olympics. Wikipedia

Don Duguid.label: Don Duguid
Don Duguid.description: Donald G. Duguid is a Canadian champion curler. A three-time winner of the Canadian Brier and two-time World Curling champion, Duguid won the Brier in 1965, 1970 and 1971, and the Worlds in 1970 and 1971. Wikipedia

Hec Gervais.label: Hec Gervais
Hec Gervais.description: Hector J. "The Friendly Giant" Gervais was a Canadian curler from Edmonton, Alberta. He was a two-time Brier champion and former World Champion. Wikipedia

Janet Harvey.label: Janet Harvey
Janet Harvey.description:
Janet Harvey is a Canadian curler.
In 1984, Harvey played second for Darcy Kirkness at that year's Canadian Junior Curling Championships. The team won the tournament, however there were no Worlds for women until 1988. Wikipedia

Jeff Stoughton.label: Jeff Stoughton
Jeff Stoughton.description: Jeff Stoughton is a Canadian curler. Stoughton is a three-time Brier champion and two-time World champion as skip. Wikipedia

Jennifer Jones (curler).label: Jennifer Jones
Jennifer Jones (curler).description: Jennifer Jones is a Canadian curler. She won an Olympic gold medal as skip of the Canadian team at the 2014 Sochi Games. She is the first female skip to go through the Games undefeated. Wikipedia

Jill Officer.label: Jill Officer
Jill Officer.description: Jill Officer is a Canadian curler from Winnipeg, Manitoba. Officer plays second for the 2005, 2008, 2009 and 2010 Scotties Tournament of Hearts champion teams skipped by Jennifer Jones. Wikipedia

John Morris (curler).label: John Morris
John Morris (curler).description: John Morris is a Canadian curler, and Vancouver 2010 Winter Olympic gold medalist from Chestermere, Alberta. Morris played third for the Kevin Martin team until 24 April 2013. He currently skips the Jim Cotter team and throw third rocks. Wikipedia

Jon Mead.label: Jon Mead
Jon Mead.description: Jonathan Mead is a Canadian curler from Winnipeg, Manitoba. Mead played third for Wayne Middaugh's rink until the end of the 2009-10 curling season. Beginning in the 2010-11 curling season, he again played third for Jeff Stoughton's Manitoba team. Wikipedia

Kevin Koe.label: Kevin Koe
Kevin Koe.description: Kevin Koe is a Canadian curler. Originally from Yellowknife, Northwest Territories, he now resides in Calgary, Alberta and curls out of Calgary, Alberta representing The Glencoe Club. Wikipedia

Kevin Park.label: Kevin Park
Kevin Park.description: Kevin Park is a Canadian curler from Edmonton, Alberta. Wikipedia

Marc Kennedy.label: Marc Kennedy
Marc Kennedy.description: Marc Kennedy is a Canadian curler, and Vancouver 2010 Winter Olympic gold medalist from St. Albert, Alberta. Kennedy currently plays second for Kevin Martin. Wikipedia

Pat McCallum.label: Pat McCallum
Pat McCallum.description: Pat McCallum is a Canadian curler. Wikipedia

Randy Dutiaume.label: Randy Dutiaume
Randy Dutiaume.description:
Randy Dutiaume is a Canadian curler from Winnipeg, Manitoba.
Dutiaume was relatively unknown to curling until 2005, having only participated in the 2003 Manitoba men's championship finishing 0-2. Wikipedia

Ryan Fry.label: Ryan Fry
Ryan Fry.description: Ryan B. Fry is a Canadian curler currently living in Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario and playing third on the Brad Jacobs team. The team represented Canada at the 2014 Winter Olympics. Wikipedia

Sandra Jenkins.label: Sandra Jenkins
Sandra Jenkins.description:
Sandra Jenkins is a Canadian curler from Salmon Arm, British Columbia.
Jenkins was the alternate player for the Canadian women's team at the 2006 Winter Olympics skipped by Shannon Kleibrink. Wikipedia

Scott Pfeifer.label: Scott Pfeifer
Scott Pfeifer.description:
Scott Pfeifer is a Canadian curler from Sherwood Park who plays out of the Saville Sports Centre in Edmonton.
Pfeifer won the '94 Canadian Junior Curling Championships and World Junior Curling Championships as a second for Colin Davison. Wikipedia

Vic Peters.label: Vic Peters
Vic Peters.description: Vic Peters is a Canadian curler from Winnipeg, Manitoba and originally from Steinbach, Manitoba. He is a three-time Manitoba curling champion, and one-time national champion having won the 1992 Labatt Brier. Wikipedia

Jake Higgs.label: Jake Higgs
Jake Higgs.description:
Jake Higgs is a Canadian curler from Strathroy, Ontario.
Higgs played second for Wayne Tuck, Jr.'s mixed team, that won a provincial championship in 2008-09, giving them the right to represent Ontario at the 2009 Canadian Mixed Curling Championship. Wikipedia

Anna Domeij.label: Anna Domeij
Anna Domeij.description: Anna Domeij is a Swedish curler. She was second for the Swedish team at the 2008 World Junior Curling Championships in Östersund, winning a silver medal. Wikipedia

Chuck Hay.label: Chuck Hay
Chuck Hay.description: Chuck Hay is a Scottish curler and World Champion. He skipped the Scottish team that won the 1967 World Curling Championships, known then as the Scotch Cup. The other members of the Scottish team were John Bryden, Alan Glen and Dave Howie. Wikipedia

Henriette Løvar.label: Henriette Løvar
Henriette Løvar.description:
Henriette Løvar is a Norwegian curler.
She was third for the Norwegian team at the 2010 Ford World Women's Curling Championship in Swift Current, Canada. Wikipedia

Ieva Krusta.label: Ieva Krusta
Ieva Krusta.description:
Ieva Krusta is a Latvian curler.
She was second for the Latvian team at the 2010 Ford World Women's Curling Championship in Swift Current, Canada.She also represented Latvia at the 2013 World Women's ... Wikipedia

Ingrid Stensrud.label: Ingrid Stensrud
Ingrid Stensrud.description:
Ingrid Stensrud is a Norwegian curler.
She was second for the Norwegian team at the 2010 Ford World Women's Curling Championship in Swift Current, Canada. Wikipedia

Iveta Staša-Šaršūne.label: Iveta Staša-Šaršūne
Iveta Staša-Šaršūne.description:
Iveta Staša-Šaršūne is a Latvian curler.
She was skip for the Latvian team at the 2010 Ford World Women's Curling Championship in Swift Current, Canada. Wikipedia

Jennifer Clark-Rouire.label: Jennifer Clark-Rouire
Jennifer Clark-Rouire.description: Jennifer Clark-Rouire is a Canadian curler. She currently throws second stones for the Karen Fallis rink out of Winnipeg, Manitoba. Wikipedia

Kristin Skaslien.label: Kristin Skaslien
Kristin Skaslien.description:
Kristin Moen Skaslien is a Norwegian curler.
She was lead for the Norwegian team at the 2010 Ford World Women's Curling Championship in Swift Current, Canada. Wikipedia

Kristin Tøsse Løvseth.label: Kristin Tøsse Løvseth
Kristin Tøsse Løvseth.description:
Kristin Tøsse Løvseth is a Norwegian curler.
She was alternate for the Norwegian team at the 2010 Ford World Women's Curling Championship in Swift Current, Canada. Wikipedia

Liselotta Lennartsson.label: Liselotta Lennartsson
Liselotta Lennartsson.description: Liselotte "Lotta" Lennartsson is a Swedish curler. She was lead for the Swedish team at the 2008 World Junior Curling Championships in Östersund, winning a silver medal. Wikipedia

Sara Carlsson.label: Sara Carlsson
Sara Carlsson.description: Sara Carlsson is a Swedish curler. She was third for the Swedish team at the 2008 World Junior Curling Championships in Östersund, winning a silver medal. Wikipedia

Sarah Reid (curler).label: Sarah Reid
Sarah Reid (curler).description:
Sarah Reid in Kilmarnock, Scotland, is a Scottish curler.
She was alternate for the Scottish team at the 2010 Ford World Women's Curling Championship in Swift Current, Saskatchewan, Canada. Wikipedia

Zanda Bikše.label: Zanda Bikše
Zanda Bikše.description:
Zanda Bikše is a Latvian curler.
She was lead for the Latvian team at the 2010 Ford World Women's Curling Championship in Swift Current, Canada. Wikipedia

Allison Pottinger.label: Allison Pottinger
Allison Pottinger.description: Allison Pottinger is an American curler from Eden Prairie, Minnesota. She currently skips her own team, but is best known as having played for Debbie McCormick in multiple Olympics and World Championships. McCormick left the team in 2010. Wikipedia

Graeme McCarrel.label: Graeme McCarrel
Graeme McCarrel.description:
Graeme McCarrel is a Canadian curler from Brampton, Ontario. He is a former Brier and World Champion. He currently plays third for Peter Corner.
In 1980, as a junior, McCarrel played third for John Kawaja. Wikipedia

Guy Hemmings.label: Guy Hemmings
Guy Hemmings.description: Guy Hemmings is a Canadian curler from Sorel. Hemmings is a popular curler who gained prominence after reaching the final of the Brier in 1998 and 1999. Wikipedia

Marco Berthelot.label: Marco Berthelot
Marco Berthelot.description:
Marco Berthelot is a Canadian curler from Longueuil, Quebec.
After playing lead for Michel Ferland at the 1991 Canadian Junior Curling Championships, Berthelot would be bumped up to third on Ferland's team and they won the Canadian Juniors in 1992. Wikipedia

Peter Corner.label: Peter Corner
Peter Corner.description: Peter Corner is a Canadian curler from Burlington, Ontario. Wikipedia

Peter Gallant.label: Peter Gallant
Peter Gallant.description:
Peter Gallant is a Canadian curler from Stratford, Prince Edward Island. He is the father of former Canadian Junior Champion Brett Gallant, and Christopher Gallant, former PEI junior champion.
Gallant has played in nine Briers. Wikipedia

Scott Bailey (curler).label: Scott Bailey
Scott Bailey (curler).description: Scott Bailey is a Canadian curler. Since 2010, he has played third for John Epping. He is known however for being the long-time lead for Wayne Middaugh. It was with Middaugh that Bailey won the 1998 Ford World Curling Championships. Wikipedia

Wayne Middaugh.label: Wayne Middaugh
Wayne Middaugh.description: Robert Wayne Middaugh is a Canadian curler from Victoria Harbour, Ontario. He is the only player to have won the Canadian Mens Curling Championship at 3 different positions Skip, Vice, and Second. Wikipedia

Annie Lemay.label: Annie Lemay
Annie Lemay.description: Annie Lemay is a Canadian curler from Gatineau, Quebec. She currently plays third for Marie-France Larouche. Wikipedia

Bryan Cochrane.label: Bryan Cochrane
Bryan Cochrane.description: Bryan Cochrane is a Canadian curler from Russell, Ontario. Cochrane is most notable for skipping team Ontario at the 2003 Nokia Brier. Wikipedia

Jean-Michel Ménard.label: Jean-Michel Ménard
Jean-Michel Ménard.description: Jean-Michel Ménard is a curler from Quebec, Canada. Ménard is notable for being the first Francophone born skip from Quebec to win the Brier - Canada's national curling championship- which he did in 2006. Wikipedia

Martin Ferland.label: Martin Ferland
Martin Ferland.description: Martin Ferland is a Canadian curler from Trois-Rivières. Wikipedia

Pierre Charette.label: Pierre Charette
Pierre Charette.description: Pierre Charette is a Canadian curler from Gatineau, Quebec. Wikipedia

Ana Arce.label: Ana Arce
Ana Arce.description: Ana Arce is a photographer and former skip of the Andorran national women's curling team. She now plays on the Spanish national team. Wikipedia

Anna Sidorova.label: Anna Sidorova
Anna Sidorova.description:
Anna Vladimirovna Sidorova is a curler from Russia. She currently skips the Russian national women's curling team.
Sidorova was a figure skater until age 13, when a leg injury forced her to give up the sport. At that point, she took up curling. Wikipedia

Erin Carmody.label: Erin Carmody
Erin Carmody.description: Erin Carmody is a Canadian curler from Prince Edward Island. A native of the town of Summerside, Carmody was a biology student at the University of Prince Edward Island when she broke onto the curling ... Wikipedia

Margarita Fomina.label: Margarita Fomina
Margarita Fomina.description:
Margarita Mikhailovna Fomina is a curler from Russia.
She was part of Ludmila Privivkova's team that won the 2006 European Curling Championships.
She received her education at the Moscow Institute of Economics and Humanities. Wikipedia

Nkeirouka Ezekh.label: Nkeirouka Ezekh
Nkeirouka Ezekh.description:
Nkeirouka Khilarievna "Kira" Ezekh is a Russian curler.
At the 2006 Winter Olympics, in Turin, Italy, she was part of Ludmila Privivkova's team. A year later her team won the 2006 European Curling Championships. Wikipedia

Robert Campbell (curler).label: Robert Campbell
Robert Campbell (curler).description:
Robert J. Campbell is a Canadian curler.
Campbell has skipped teams in six Briers; played third at the 2002 Brier for John Likely and played lead in 2007 for Peter Gallant, and was an alternate in the 2001 Brier. Wikipedia

Robyn MacPhee.label: Robyn MacPhee
Robyn MacPhee.description:
Robyn MacPhee is a Canadian curler. She formerly played second for Suzanne Birt.
MacPhee played both second and third for Birt during their junior careers. Wikipedia

Suzanne Birt.label: Suzanne Birt
Suzanne Birt.description: Suzanne Birt is a Canadian curler from Covehead, Prince Edward Island. Wikipedia

Zang Jialiang.label: Zang Jialiang
Zang Jialiang.description:
Zang Jialiang is an internationally elite curler who trains out of Harbin, China.
He made his world championship debut at the 2008 Grand Forks World Championships. Team China achieved their best result to date. Wikipedia

Brad Jacobs (curler).label: Brad Jacobs
Brad Jacobs (curler).description: Brad Jacobs is a Canadian curler. Jacobs is the skip of the 2013 Tim Hortons Brier championship team and 2013 World Championship runner-up and is a five-time Northern Ontario provincial champion, and one time provincial junior champion. Wikipedia

Daryl Shane.label: Daryl Shane
Daryl Shane.description: Daryl Shane is a Canadian curler from Waterloo, Ontario. He is a former provincial junior champion. He presently skips a men's team on the Ontario Curling Tour, and has played on the World Curling Tour in past seasons. Wikipedia

Imogen Oona Lehmann.label: Imogen Oona Lehmann
Imogen Oona Lehmann.description:
Imogen Oona Lehmann is a Swiss-German curler. She is a member of the German national women's team. She is originally from Basel, Switzerland.
Oona Lehmann played her junior career in her native Switzerland. Wikipedia

Jamie Danbrook.label: Jamie Danbrook
Jamie Danbrook.description:
Jamie Danbrook is a Canadian curler.
Danbrook won three provincial junior titles for two different provinces. In 2005 and 2008, he won the British Columbia junior titles. Wikipedia

Jamie Sinclair.label: Jamie Sinclair
Jamie Sinclair.description:
Jamie Ann Sinclair is an American-Canadian curler from Manotick, Ontario.
She was born in Anchorage, Alaska.
Sinclair won a gold medal at the 2007 Canada Winter Games, playing lead for the Rachel Homan rink. Wikipedia

Jessica Mair.label: Jessica Mair
Jessica Mair.description:
Jessica Mair is a Canadian curler. She plays second for the 2012 national champion Heather Nedohin rink.
Before joining the Nedohin rink, Mair was a top collegiate curler. In 2005, she won the Alberta collegiate championship. Wikipedia

Lisa Weagle.label: Lisa Weagle
Lisa Weagle.description: Lisa Weagle is a Canadian curler from Ottawa, Ontario. Weagle is the lead on the team skipped, or captained, by Rachel Homan out of the Ottawa Curling Club. Wikipedia

Anna Ohmiya.label: Anna Ohmiya
Anna Ohmiya.description:
Anna Ohmiya is a Japanese curler, born October 12, 1989 in Tokoro District, Hokkaidō, Japan.
Member of Team Aomori, Ohmiya competed at the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver, Canada for Team Japan. Wikipedia

Corinna Scholz.label: Corinna Scholz
Corinna Scholz.description: Corinna Scholz is a German curler from Bernbeuren. She will compete as the Alternate when she represents Germany at the 2010 Winter Olympics. Wikipedia

Jim Armstrong (curler).label: Jim Armstrong
Jim Armstrong (curler).description: James P. Armstrong is a former Canadian curler and current wheelchair curler now living in Ontario. He was a successful able-bodied curler for much of his career until he had to stop playing because of bad knees and a car accident in 2003. Wikipedia

Liu Jinli.label: Liu Jinli
Liu Jinli.description:
Liu Jinli is an internationally elite curler from China.
She curls out of the club in Heilongjiang and is currently a member of the Chinese National Team. Wikipedia

Mikkel Poulsen.label: Mikkel Poulsen
Mikkel Poulsen.description:
Mikkel Adrup Poulsen is an internationally elite curler from Denmark.
He made his world championship debut at the 2008 World Championships in Grand Forks, USA. He also competed at the 2009 Moncton World Championships. Wikipedia

Sabrina Kraupp.label: Sabrina Kraupp
Sabrina Kraupp.description: Sabrina Kraupp is a Swedish curler. She was alternate for the Swedish team at the 2005 World Junior Curling Championships in Pinerolo, winning a silver medal. Wikipedia

Stella Heiß.label: Stella Heiß
Stella Heiß.description: Stella Heiß is a German curler from Garmisch-Partenkirchen. She played lead for Andrea Schöpp when she represented Germany at the 2010 Winter Olympics in Curling. At seventeen years, she was the youngest curler at the Games. Wikipedia

Dale Matchett.label: Dale Matchett
Dale Matchett.description: Dale Matchett is a Canadian curler from Alliston, Ontario. Matchett is a former provincial junior curling champion and a regular on the World Curling Tour. Wikipedia
